This issue also seems to also cause problems with Application Links in JIRA. The Symptom is that JIRA appears to be slow to update information in the Development Panel ('Dev Panel') with wait times up to 30 minutes for information to be up to date.

h4. Workaround

Root cause investigation is ongoing but the possible culprit is an improperly starting plugin. This issue has been known to resolve itself with an application restart but if you do encounter this error please provide an application Support Zip to Support at https://support.atlassian.com so that we can investigate further.

{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi,

Good news! In Bitbucket Server 7.1 we shipped Push log feature that can help you find the author and date of creation for a branch. For more information, please read Bitbucket Server 7.1 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-1-release-notes-998641213.html] and Push log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/push-logs-998882984.html].

Alternatively, the same information can be found Audit log starting from Bitbucket Data Center 7.2, if the coverage level of _End-user activity_ is set to _Advanced_. For more information, please read Audit log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/audit-log-events-in-bitbucket-776640423.html].

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original message*

For audit sake and the "branch owner/creator" I'd like to see in the branches view who created the branch or any hover/metadata that can be viewed on the branch life.
fields.summary: Show name of who created branch

fields.description:
As a deployed, given a list of commits about to be deployed I would like to be able to see who approved those commits, so that I can have confidence that the code has had sufficient code review.

I currently achieve this with a script that does the following:
* Identify merge commits with a message matching "Merge pull request #(\d+)"
* For each, hit the stash API to get the list of commits in the PR and approvers.
* Identify commits that do not have a matching PR - assume they have not been reviewed.

This is not ideal for a few reasons:
1. I have to have the git repository checked out locally to get the right set of commits and check for merge commits.
2. It misses any PRs that are merged with a custom description.
3. It prevents use of fast-forward merges. These are often preferable since they don't require a rebuild of master through CI.

A couple of potential solutions (just some ideas, may be a better way to solve this):
* Expose an API that given a commit, tells me what PRs (if any) it was in.
* Have Stash add a signed note to each commit including the approvers. (hrmm ... could maybe do this in a plugin?) (Note: can't use in-built git commit signing because it requires amending the commit, which breaks #3 above)
fields.summary: Finding out who reviewed a commit.

fields.description:
STASH-2910 added the option for an additional (per-branch) restriction to block "Changes without a pull request"

However, this is an option that applies for all users, rather than "allowing only a restricted set of users to push but allowing all to merge a pull request" (which was the original summary to STASH-2910)

It would be very useful to have these additional options be able to be bypassed by certain users/groups. Use case:

 - Commits to the release branches have to be done through pull requests, but the ci server (which isn't an access key user, so this isn't the same as STASH-5009) can do release builds and update versions in pom.xml files.

Note that the users with this permission must be managed separately to the list of users with write access to the branch, otherwise the use case of 'developers do their own merges to the branch after an approved pull request' won't work.

It may be useful to also apply this to the other two options added in stash 3.10 ("rewriting history" and "branch deletion"), but the pull request restriction is more useful, at least to me.
fields.summary: Allow only certain users to make changes without a pull request

fields.description:
Currently the [Repository Ref Synchronization|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.9.2/stash-repository-ref-sync-rest.html] link can be found in the dropdown list {{More > REST}} in the [Stash Docs|https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/], but it's not listed in the body of the document, so customers may not find it.

In addition, the first result I get when searching for "stash rest api" in google is [https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/reference/rest-api.html], so I suggest to add this document on the body of this page as well.
fields.summary: Add Repository Ref Synchronization to the body of the REST API docs

fields.description:
Changes in git's error messages cause Stash to misinterpret certain errors from git, which may produce undesirable results.

Changes are caused by error message format changes in git's refs.c:

https://github.com/git/git/commit/faa4b2ecbb6ea5fdc8d685343c4985dfb97f4dbf#diff-e3d30a16dfc234b7f6c1129955f5c0ac

and mean instead of {{*RefNameException}} Stash's git code throws {{CommandFailedException}}.
fields.summary: Changes to error messages in Git 2.4.3 cause Stash to misinterpret them

fields.description:
Hello,

I'm on a retina iMac which is very high resolution and I'm sure any other high resolution OS especially without good Mac scaling would make on screen text small.  The source code view from Stash seems to have rather small text and I'd like to be able to control that as admin for my stash server such as using a CSS or some admin setting.  The color coding also seems a bit odd, we use C# .NET.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Add CSS support for source code view or some control of font size

fields.description:
Hello,

I have a case open with SourceTree support but I figured I'd ping you as well.  When using the SourceTree app on both Mac and Windows it seems that we are not getting notifications of changes (desktop notifications) etc. very well with Stash.  It seems better from GitHub also registered in SourceTree as a remote.  I've tried polling intervals in SourceTree of 10, 5, and 1 minutes, allow background refresh is enabled, etc.  Without getting too much into SourceTree settings, my concern is the Stash server is potentially slow in notifying maybe via the API SourceTree uses of updates.  I have tried both SSH and HTTPS protocols.  I'm using Stash on my Windows Server 2012 R2 server against a MS SQL 2014 server with the database configured as per your Stash installation documentation.

Thank you

Neal Culiner
NC Software, Inc.
fields.summary: Slow notifications with SourceTree when changes available (commits etc)

fields.description:
Provide visual notification for pull requests that may be in conflict with each other in the following views:
1. Pull Requests view: add visual warning indicator when PRs that target the same branch may be in conflict.
2. Pull Request view: Add visual indication on the PR review screen that the pull request may be in conflict with another active PR.
3. When PR is in the process of creation, indicate that the PR may be in conflict with another existing and active PR. If created anyways, send notification to both authors that competing PRs are in play.
fields.summary: In pull requests view, predict if PRs targeting the same branch may be in conflict

fields.description:
Currently when using the image diff in a pull request, switching to a different mode is not persisted.

When pixel diff mode was selected and the user switches to a different file, the mode is back to two-up again. It would be nice if this was locally stored, so that pixel diff mode loads when going to the next image.
fields.summary: Image diff: Remember last used mode when switching between files
Support Markdown image URLs with spaces

fields.summary: Incomplete surrogate pair

fields.description:
Case:

Want to add "Åbjörnsson, Alexander" to reviewers.
Type "å", nothing shows up.
Type "A", Åbjörnsson, *A*lexander" shows up.

Expected:
Åbjörnsson, Alexander should show up in both cases.
fields.summary: User's name starting with Å/Ä/Ö don't show up when searching with lower case letter when making pull requests

fields.description:
I am creating a README.md file with an anchor tag to one of the headings . The anchor tag is rendered properly but I am facing an issue with the redirecion of the hyperlink. Whenever I click on the hyperlink, it always redirects me to the **default branch** of the repository , instead of the branch where I am currently in.

For ex, I have this anchor tag in my README.md file
{code}[About](#about){code}

When i click on the link, it redirects me to 
{{http://my.stash.server/Stash/projects/PROJ/repos/repo/browse/README.md#about?at=refs%2Fheads%2Fbranch}}

Even though the link has the words *at=refs%2Fheads%2Fbranch* in it, the redirection always ends up in the default branch , which is master 

is there anything that can be done in the markdown syntax  so that it redirects to the current branch instead of master ?
fields.summary: Stash Readme.md anchor tags always redirect to default branch

fields.description: I'd like to mark particular repo as favourite which will let me organise my work.
fields.summary: Favourite repos

fields.description:
Currently Stash bundles Tomcat 8.0.15.

Tomcat 8.0.23 has recently been released. It includes fixes for a TLS issue present in 8.0.22, and it also includes a workaround for an SPNEGO regression introduced in Java 8u40 (and also present in Java 8u45).
fields.summary: Upgrade to Tomcat 8.0.23

fields.description:
After upgrading to Stash 3.9, some pull requests hang for long periods trying to display the diff. When the diff is eventually displayed, the pull request indicates the diff has conflicts but none are shown.

This can also manifest as a lengthy (~5 minute) delay merging pull requests, after which the pull request ultimately fails to merge. A "Server unreachable" error will be shown after ~1 minute due to STASH-7360, but refreshing shows that the merge didn't ever complete.

*This regression is only possible on cross-repository pull requests.* Pull requests between branches within a single repository use a different process which does not have this issue.
fields.summary: Cross-repository pull request merges sometimes fail to fetch objects after upgrading to Stash 3.9

fields.description: The branch selector seems to sort in alphabetical view. It would be nice if the exact matches are either pushed to the top (and separated from the aphabetical sort), or have it be selected by default. At the moment, i have to manually scroll to find it, which makes it quite slow/hard if there are a lot of branches.
fields.summary: branch selector should sort exact matches higher

fields.description:
This is probably related to STASH-6910, but not marking as a duplicate as I'm not sure.

If you create a new empty branch and push to stash, the hipchat notification is:

{code}
5+ commits pushed to branch ...
- 1 desc
- 2 desc
- 3 desc
- 4 desc
- 5 desc
See more
{code}

The code in com.atlassian.stash.internal.hipchat.hook.HipChatNotificationRenderer#getCommits doesn't work properly for new branches, as it gets all commits from 00000 to branch head.

Tested on 3.7 but the code is still unchanged in 3.8.0, which is latest source I have access to atm.
fields.summary: branch creation message in hipchat notification inaccurate

fields.description:
As a Stash User with only read access to project or repo
When I create a Pull Request
I would like to have a list of users who have merge access to the repo
so that I can add them as reviewers and eventually have them merge the PR

The problem I have when I create pull request is that I do not know who have merge access. And before I only have read access, I cannot see the Settings tab, to find out who have merge access. Becoming a chicken and egg thingy.

Hence recommending to have a section beneath or right side of the "Reviewers" box, showing collapsed `Repo mergers` and `Project mergers` (or have `Project Mergers` as the last option for `Repo Mergers`)
fields.summary: Shows who have merge access when creating Pull Request

fields.description:
This looks ugly

!http://monosnap.com/image/SJdVuhFRT9mmyUB3Uh9K6qNeJ3v5ue.png!

Note that this was happening when there was an error loading the recent repo list... so maybe it only happens when recent repos is broken
fields.summary: Overlap between Projects and "Recent Projects" tab in header

fields.description:
The Overview tab within Pull Requests is updated by every comment made on the diff, i.e. the comment shows up at the top of the list in the Overview tab. However replies to comments do not go to the top, in a way the user must scroll to find it. 

That being said, the feature is not useful for replies, as they may get lost for not showing up in the top of the Overview. 

*Steps to check this*
# Create a Pull Request.
# Add a comment to the PR. Check it shows up at the top of the Overview tab.

fields.description:
Not sure if this is the right place to report this...

The Postgres scripts for the DIY backup option support the parallel option (-j). However, this is misspelt in the code - the variable that is set (and used for backups) is PG_PARALLELL but the variable used for restores is PG_PARALLEL. Due to this mis-spelling, parallel mode isn't used for a restore.

Pull request is at https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/atlassian-stash-diy-backup/pull-request/15/misc-fixes-for-the-diy-backup-scripts; this also disables the verbose rsync pption when verbose backups are disabled.
fields.summary: Stash DIY restores with postgres don't use the PARALLEL option

A quick change to the CSS would fix this up nicely.

As a workaround, could you let me know what I'd need to do to patch the CSS on my own? Is there a way of customizing the rendering of Markdown pages in Stash?

fields.description:
Hi,

I am verifying my diy backups to make sure I can restore but it's not working for me.

The postscript function stash_backup_db uses format option '-Fd'
    pg_dump ${PG_USER} ${PG_HOST} --port=${POSTGRES_PORT} ${PG_PARALLELL} -Fd ${STASH_DB} ${PG_SNAPSHOT_OPT} -f ${STASH_BACKUP_DB}

and the pg_restore_db uses the same thing.  But when I tried to restore I got a failure:
pg_restore: unrecognized archive format "d"; please specify "c" or "t"

Looking at the man pages (I have postgresql 8.4) neither pg_dump or pg_restore have "d" listed as a valid format option.  pg_dump lists p,c,t and pg_restore only lists c and t.   I tried to restore using '-Ft' and the error became :
pg_restore: [tar archiver] could not find header for file toc.dat in tar archive

So I then tried '-Fc' and the error became
pg_restore: [archiver] unexpected end of file

So then I tried leaving out the -F argument altogether and the error became
pg_restore: [archiver] could not read input file: Is a directory

I checked the latest stash-diy-backup-postgresql code and the functions look unchanged from what I have.  

I am worried that my backups are all invalid.  Is there a way to restore one of them?

Which format should I use going forward?

Thanks
Mark
fields.summary: stash.diy-backup.postgresql.sh function stash_restore_db fails with PostgreSQL 8.4

fields.description: With the changes for STASH-2744, Stash creates one rescope request for every ref modified during a push. fields.description:
Since Stash 3.8 the {{server.xml}} configuration file is no longer local to the Stash installation directory (and thus not carried over automatically on upgrade to new versions) but is read from {{$STASH_HOME/shared/server.xml}}.

If this file is later deleted or made unreadable Stash would fail to start and report an error.

In 3.9.2+ a default {{.default-server.xml}} is now created by the Stash Installer and used in case {{server.xml}} is missing or unreadable from all of {{$STASH_HOME}}, {{$STASH_HOME/shared}}, and the Stash installation directory.
fields.summary: Provide fallback .default-server.xml in case $STASH_HOME/shared/server.xml is missing or unreadable

I was informed that Stash's MarkupRendererComponent is "only active for pull request comments and descriptions" during a discussion on this thread:[https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15699871].

fields.description:
When an OutOfMemoryError occurs in certain contexts, the Hazelcast instance is terminated which prevents Stash on that cluster node from potentially recovering from the error.

OutOfMemoryErrors are not always recoverable anyway, but this behaviour of Hazelcast when it is caught in these contexts should be made more robust.  This will remove some occurrences of the following log error:

{code}
2015-01-05 01:36:21,091 ERROR [threadpool:thread-36072]  c.a.s.i.c.StateTransferringExecutor Error while processing asynchronous task
com.atlassian.cache.CacheException: com.hazelcast.core.HazelcastInstanceNotActiveException: Hazelcast instance is not active!
        at com.atlassian.cache.hazelcast.HazelcastCachedReference.get(HazelcastCachedReference.java:95) ~[HazelcastCachedReference.class:na]
        at com.atlassian.stash.internal.license.LicenseServiceImpl.get(LicenseServiceImpl.java:101) ~[LicenseServiceImpl.class:na]
{code}

fields.description:
Hello,

Been using Stash and Bamboo for about a month now and really like it but they both have a similar problem, showing inherited permissions in lower levels.  For example, in Stash you can set project permission and then further down on a repository its own permissions.  It would be nice if when viewing a repo that you could see what permissions are already in affect inherited from the project level.  In bamboo the same applies, you have global permissions and then build/plan permissions but you can't see (or remember) what the higher level permissions are.

Please consider some type of "ghosting" or presentation of existing permissions so they are not duplicated or messed up at a lower level.  In Bamboo I'm also seeing where I have anonymous off globally but when I create a new plan anonymous seems to get checked - probably a bug.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Show inherited permissions in repository from Project permissions

fields.description:
I'd like the ability to set a "manual" mode for automatic branch merging in Stash. The semantic versioning scheme doesn't always make sense. Perhaps I have a lot of ad-hoc branch names modeled around our own internal process and we do not use the semantic versioning approach.

I still would like the ability to utilize Stash to maintain parity between the branches with transparent and continuous merges. Right now I'm forced to do so by hand on a less-than-ideal frequency because my branch names do not correlate to version numbers.

My proposal:

Add a checkbox or mode called "Manual" or something along those lines. When enabled, two panes activate and become visible. Left side is a list of "Branches to automatically merge" and the right side is "Available branches". From the right side, I should be able to drag & drop branches onto the left panel. The left panel will also allow me to drag & drop items to reorder them from within itself.

Think of how the Issue Schemes work in JIRA. When you configure a scheme, you can drag & drop issues left & right and reorder them. This exact same widget / style should be used here too.

Order of the branches in the left panel determines the merge direction. From top to bottom, the merges will take place. So let's say I have the following branches in the left panel (ordered as shown):

* develop-hardware1
* develop
* develop-hardware2

Merges will occur in the following order:

`develop-hardware1 --> develop --> develop-hardware2`

I should be able to click SAVE or CONFIRM at this point to save the configuration which will make automatic merging effective immediately.
fields.summary: Allow manual configuration of branches in automatic merging

fields.description:

On the contrary, we end up in confusing situations where ticket had one text in the summary, and then the summary was changed to something else. Now we have several cases where different repositories have differently named branches for the same ticket.

Can we have a system-level setting where there's a toggle between "use ticket only" vs "use ticket and summary" for the branch names?

Example.
Action > Update my current repo
git remote -v (Verify current settings)
git remote set-url <repo reference(origin/stash/ect> <Stash Link>

Personally I would have it appear as follows

>Update repository to work with Stash

fields.description:
Fresh Windows Server 2003 R2 32-bit, just installed in a VM.
Oracle JDK 1.8 is not compatible with Windows Server 2003 R2 (it can be installed, but won't work correctly), so I've installed Oracle JDK 1.7 32-bit which is deprecated but should be okay to use it.
Downloaded Stash 3.9.1 Windows Installer 32-bit and tried to install it this way:
Step 1: Install a new Stash instance
Step 2: Destination Directory: {{C:\Atlassian\Apps\Stash\3.9.1}}
Step 3: Stash Home: {{C:\Atlassian\Data\Stash\3.9.1}}
Step 4: Startup menu (default settings)
Step 5: TCP Ports (default settings)
Step 6: Run as Service (selected). After clicking "Next" a message said:
{noformat}
It looks like a Stash service is already installed in the target environment.
The installation will replace any existing services. Do you want to continue?
{noformat}
Clicked "Yes"
Step 7: Clicked "Install"
The installer started extracting files, but after waiting for more than 30 minutes, it hadn't finished yet.
I tried to cancel the installation, but the installer never exited, so I had to kill the installer process using the Windows Task Manager.

Uninstalled Stash completely.

Tried to install Stash again, this time *not* installing the Windows service.
The installer completed in less than two minutes.
I didn't start Stash after the installer finished (last installer step).
Before starting the instance, I've verified STASH_HOME at {{C:\Atlassian\Apps\Stash\3.9.1\bin\setenv.bat}}
I manually executed {{C:\Atlassian\Apps\Stash\3.9.1\bin\start-stash.bat}}. The Command Prompt opened and closed immediately.
So, opened Command Prompt, navigated to {{C:\Atlassian\Apps\Stash\3.9.1\bin}} and executed {{start-stash.bat}}
I got this output:
{noformat}
To run Stash in the foreground, start the server with start-stash.bat /fg

Using STASH_HOME: C:\\Atlassian\\Data\\Stash\\3.9.1
{noformat}
Nothing else displayed.
Checked the Stash Home directory, and only a {{shared}} directory existed.

The instance won't start up.

All these steps have been done with the Windows default administrator, which should have full permissions. Even so, I've checked the user permissions in both installation directory ({{C:\Atlassian\Apps\Stash\3.9.1}}) and Stash Home ({{C:\Atlassian\Data\Stash\3.9.1}}), and ensured the folders allowed full permissions to the Administrator user.
fields.summary: Stash Installer will not work with Windows Server 2003 R2 32-bit

fields.description:
Stash 3.8 introduced filtering of unlicensed users, which were previously being returned in user searches such as those used by the \@mention functionality. There however exists a performance regression for Stash instances where there is a large disparity between the number of licensed vs unlicensed users.

To reproduce this problem:
# Have just one or two licensed users in Stash
# Sync an LDAP directory of > 10,000 users to Stash (Say the users all have an email address with domain _example.com_)
# On a comment type "@ex"
# After 30s the following error dialog is presented:

!mention-error.png!

The server will continue running the search even after this error occurs, however the result set will never be utilised in the UI.

It is also possible to reproduce this slowness via the REST interface. No error occurs but such a query on the same Stash instance as described above will take many minutes and eventually return the one or two licensed users (if they match the query string).

{noformat}
curl -u admin:admin 'http://localhost:7990/stash/rest/api/latest/users?avatarSize=48&permission=LICENSED_USER&filter=ex'
{noformat}

Root cause: Crowd search interface (ApplicationServiceGeneric.search()) is inefficient when paging is used. For each page the database is queried (with the filter text) and the entire result is read into memory. There is no limit put on the result, so in the above example the result set consists of all 10,000 users, even if we are interested in only the first 25.

So with a page size of 25, and 10,000 users in the directory, the query is executed 400 times. If we set a page size of 10,000 the query is run just once.

Although inefficient, Crowd does this for good reasons, described in CWD-2807. The obvious use of selection (via OFFSET & LIMIT) in the query is not viable.

Currently this problem has the ability to seriously degrade the performance of a Stash instance. This issue intends to work around the issue by using a large page size.
fields.summary: Performance regression for instances with a large disparity of licensed to unlicensed users

fields.description:
It appears that a user can decline a pull request if and only if he/she can merge it (i.e., has write access to its target).  It's unfortunate that the 'decline' and 'merge' privileges are conflated, because someone with merge privileges not only determines what can be merged to the target branch, but also when and in what order PRs are pulled.

In our workflow, we have "gatekeepers" who make one-time decisions on whether or not a PR may be allowed on a particular target branch.  However, the gatekeepers are not the people responsible for controlling when fixes go in and in which order.  Only the latter needs write privileges to the branch; the gatekeepers do not.  Related to this, our gatekeepers vary by area of the code being touched, so we have multiple gatekeepers and do not want to give all of them write privs.  We would like the ability to configure the gatekeepers' privileges so they can decline (and approve) PRs but not merge them.

There are several ways to implement my request, and I'm not advocating for a particular one.  E.g.:
* Add a permission level.
* Add a toggle that determines whether 'read' has 'decline' privileges or not.
* Separate privileges ('can view PRs', 'can decline PRs', 'can merge PRs', etc.) from roles ('reader', 'branch captain', 'admin', etc.) and provide a mechanism to map privileges to roles (ala JIRA).

Ref. https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15283277/stash-permission-to-decline-pull-request-but-not-merge.
fields.summary: Permission to decline pull request but not merge

fields.description:
In the current versions of Stash, once SSH is enabled it is a free for all.  Any user of Stash is able to add any number of SSH keys to their profile, they can add keys from servers, desktops, even home computers and there is no control from an administrator point of view and there is no ability to prevent keys from unapproved systems.  This request is to consider two possible alternatives:

Alternative 1) Add the Ability to restrict users who are not members of select groups from adding SSH keys in their profile.  Each admin could set up their own process for how their users to submit their public key to the Stash Administrator (email, support tickets, IM, etc) who would then have to add the provided key for that user. This will prevent from users adding too many keys (or keys from unapproved machines)  In this way administrators are in control of which entities have access to Stash via SSH.

Alternative 2) Provide a workflow from within Stash that users are able to request that their SSH key be added to their profile.  Requests would then be approved or denied by an administrator before they become active.  Requests that are not approved would alert the user that their request was denied and the key would never become active.  Requests that are approved would instantly become active.
fields.summary: Add the ability for Stash admins to prevent users from adding their own SSH keys to their profile

fields.description:
Stash currently allows you to retain approvals when more changes are pushed or remove all approvals when changes are pushed. I'd like to suggest another option that sits in the middle.

I like to leave Stash with the retain approvals option because if I only suggest trivial changes such as spelling or formatting issues, I'm also happy to approve it so I don't have to look again just for trivial changes. However, if a large number of changes are pushed, I'd like to re-review the PR.

Our current process is that the developer should notify reviewers that large changes have been made but I'd rather have this as part of the Stash workflow. What about adding a button that allows the PR creator to reset approvals. In the same example, after pushing a large number of changes, the developer would simply press this button to remove all approvals and notify the reviewers so they can re-review the PR.

I wondered if this could be further improved by automating the decision based on the number of changes introduced in the diff (either by percentage or number of lines or files) so if it higher than a certain threshold, all approvals are automatically removed. While this would be ideal because it is no longer up to the developer to decide if the changes are large or not, I can see it being difficult to get the threshold correct.
fields.summary: Allow PR creator to reset/remove approvals

fields.description:
In the Permission screen, when you add an existing user.. the message being displayed is "No Matching Users Found" when indeed, the user is already added that's why it's not showing up.

_Note: We have a very long list so searching for the ID in the page won't do because you need to scroll all the way down to load the complete list._
fields.summary: Improve the error message when adding an existing user

fields.description:
When viewing a diff that has a horizontal scroll bar, that scroll bar does not work until the source list is collapsed.  After expanding the source list, refreshing the page, or selecting a different file from the source list with a horizontal scroll bar, the scroll bar continues to work.

Unfortunately, I haven't uncovered any pattern for when it stops working.
fields.summary: Horizontal scroll in diff view does not work until source list is collapsed

fields.description:
If I have two branches with the same changes in different commits, Stash's branch comparison is misleading.

I have created a demonstration git repository (attached). In it, I created the file two.txt on both 'master' and 'a_branch'. I then made further modifications to this file on 'master'.

However, Stash's compare (see screenshot) is showing the line 'file two' as being a new addition when merging 'master' into 'a_branch'. Furthermore, it is claiming two.txt is a new file (it's shown in green text on the left panel), when it already exists in 'a_branch'!

In terms of git's CLI, I would expect this:

{code}
$ PAGER=cat git diff a_branch..master
diff --git a/file_created_in_branch.txt b/file_created_in_branch.txt
deleted file mode 100644
index d673e5e..0000000
--- a/file_created_in_branch.txt
+++ /dev/null
@@ -1 +0,0 @@
-created file in a_branch
diff --git a/file_created_in_master.txt b/file_created_in_master.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..9dc7d06
--- /dev/null
+++ b/file_created_in_master.txt
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+this file was only created in master!
diff --git a/two.txt b/two.txt
index 6c970db..135327c 100644
--- a/two.txt
+++ b/two.txt
@@ -1 +1,2 @@
 file two
+modification in master
{code}

However, Stash seems to be doing the equivalent of this (three dots!):

{code}
$ PAGER=cat git diff a_branch...master
diff --git a/file_created_in_master.txt b/file_created_in_master.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..9dc7d06
--- /dev/null
+++ b/file_created_in_master.txt
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+this file was only created in master!
diff --git a/two.txt b/two.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..135327c
--- /dev/null
+++ b/two.txt
@@ -0,0 +1,2 @@
+file two
+modification in master
{code}

This has bitten our users several times: they become reluctant to create pull requests because they think the merge would include more changes than they expected. As a result, they lose trust in branch comparison tool.
fields.summary: Stash's branch compare starts at a common ancestor, so the diff shown is misleading
Stash's 'already tracked by git' commands assume an origin already exists

fields.description:
As far as I can tell, currently, you can only search for repositories. This is pretty useless since the number of repositories is usually pretty small.

On the other hand, I frequently want to search pull requests, either for a commit id, so I can see the pull request it is associated with, or for somthing in the description.

It would also be nice to be able to search branches in a repository, although that isn't as critical since I can use git commands to do that.
fields.summary: Ability to search Pull Requests

fields.description: I need to create a TOC for a markdown page and it looks like IDs are stripped from headers so the links in the TOC won't work.
fields.summary: Header / TOC links don't work in Stash v3.7.1

fields.description:
This is due to an issue in Crowd, which only affects uncached directories. 
Directories are cached by default however.
Since it is not possible to configure an uncached directory in JIRA as a Crowd Server, this will not affect Stash instances using JIRA for auth.

See CWD-4338 for further details and status.
fields.summary: Crowd directories which are uncached containing group memberships with a space in the group/username will cause a unique constraint or index violation; UK_MEM_DIR_PARENT_CHILD table: CWD_MEMBERSHIP when Stash is using MySQL

fields.description:
Pull requests and commits have a diff view that shows the files which have changed.

That's great.

Could you please provide an option (e.g. checkbox that can be checked/unchecked) to also show the files which have *not* changed? (and if they are shown, visually distinguish them from the ones that have changed)

I agree that seeing only the files that have changed is useful to focus on things, but sometimes you need to view them in context, and it is very cumbersome in Stash to be able to look at the source files for the state of the repo branch at that commit.
fields.summary: provide option to show both changed and unchanged files in diff views (commit, pull request)
